docs.lead_paragraph: SSL International, the maker of Durex condoms, does not have a new partner, despite reports to the contrary, executives close to the company and its rumored buyer say.

headline.main: Rumors of Suitor for Condom Maker Said to Be Untrue

docs.abstract: SSL International, the maker of Durex condoms, does not have a new partner, despite reports to the contrary, executives close to the company and its rumored buyer say. Talk swirled through London markets Monday that the company, which also owns the foot care brand Scholl, and cough syrup and pregnancy test businesses, was going to [...]

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Jonathan Rauch's discussion of ''The Party of Death,'' by Ramesh Ponnuru (Sept. 3), was most welcome. However, one small point needs to be made. Rauch asks if evena life-threatening (to the mother, we assume)pregnancy could be aborted if abortion were to be considered infanticide. Heclaims that we do not have a ''health exception'' to the murder laws. Yes, we do; it is called self-defense. Arlene Kalley Troy, Mich. To the Editor: As a hard-line abortion rights supporter, I want to clear up a confusion in Rauch's mind between private moral considerations and public law. Abortion rights supporters have never said that a 10-day-old embryo is morally comparable to an appendix, or that pregnancy is comparable to appendicitis.I have argued that the decision to get an abortion should be a private decision by the pregnant woman -- no more regulated by the state than the decision to get an appendectomy. Pregnancy can pose moral, social, economic, emotional or medical problems for a woman that only an abortion can solve. Inserting the government into those considerations is what we abortion supporters want to avoid. If a woman becomes attached to a pregnancy and toher childwhen it is an embryo -- as your reviewer's friend did -- then of course she should carry thepregnancy to term and have the baby. We pro-choice peoplebelieve that the creation of human lifeshould always involve the willing cooperation of the woman in whose body it is going to happen. Adriane Ann Wallace Stamford, Conn
